title: ACADEMIC SELF-PERCEPTION AND ITS RELATIONSHIP TO ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE
abstract: One hundred and fifty-five students (average age, 10 years 7 months) were initially tested on reading, arithmetic, and academic self-perception. One year later they were tested again. Initial academic scores accounted for a large proportion of the variance in later academic scores. The children's self-perceptions of academic competence accounted for significant variance in academic performance one year later. However, neither the academic self-perceptions at the beginning of the study nor changes in self-perceptions over time predicted changes in academic performance. Self-percep ion of academic competence cannot play a simple, causal role in academic achieve ment.

abstract.text: One hundred and fifty-five students (average age, 10 years 7 months) were initially tested on reading, arithmetic, and academic self-perception. One year later they were tested again. Initial academic scores accounted for a large proportion of the variance in later academic scores. The children's self-perceptions of academic competence accounted for significant variance in academic performance one year later. However, neither the academic self-perceptions at the beginning of the study nor changes in self-perceptions over time predicted changes in academic performance. Self-percep ion of academic competence cannot play a simple, causal role in academic achieve ment.

body_text.text: A major focus of cognitive educational psychology is growth or decline in academic performance. Some area success: cognitive psychology has made great strides in chief sources of variance in reading ability (Stanovich, 19 children's abilities of phonemic awareness and phonolo may account for as much as 50 per cent of the variance in (Stanovich, 1988) . Although this research represents accomplishment and has enormous implications for effect in reading, much variance remains to be accounted for this "extraphonological" variance is occurring in many realms, such as temporal processing (Farmer & Klein, processing (Kail & Hall, 1994) , perceptual processes su visual perception (Breitmeyer, 1989) , and auditory percept "p-centre" (Goswami et al., 2002) . Researchers have al variance in environmental factors, such as SES effects, nu in the home, and parents' time spent in reading to chi these environmental factors do not account for a great d reading ability and may eventually fade in significance borough & Dobrich, 1994a borough & Dobrich, , 1994b , especially as sch effective methods of instruction.

The attempt to identify the cognitive processes in acquisition of mathematics skills is much less develop cesses may be involved, and several have been the subject Although there has been study of higher level, doma cesses, such as executive processes (Geary, Hoard & Ha semantic memory (Geary, Haamson & Hoard, 2000; G 2001) , or working memory (Geary, 1993) , processes domain of mathematics would seem to be more promising interest is initial work in numerosity (Landerl, Bevan 2004) , the basic sense of number tapped by Piagetian co (Gelman & Gallistel, 1978) . Small units of number are cessed without counting, a process called "subitization."

There are also factors believed to account decline in academic performance that are ex factors more in the realm of the psycholog Of these, one factor that has seen a signi moderate degree of controversy, is self-e relationship to academic performance. This to elucidate the history of this belief be dously large project. However, recent re meister, Campbell, Krueger and Vohs (2003) some detail. At various levels of analy positive self-concept has been shown to b positive outcomes. There is, however, ver lish that this relationship is causal.

There are rational, principled reasons t concept might influence academic perfor which this relationaship may occur have self-affirmation (Steele, 1988) All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms concept or self-perception (Renick & Harter, 1988) , seems self-perception of competence in the academic domain. In with learning disabilities (LD) have been shown to ma self-esteem or general self-worth comparable to normally dents despite lowered levels of self-perceived academ (Heath, 1995; Heath & Glen, 2005) . Different levels of asse versus domain-specific, can yield different results rega self-concept.

This match between levels of assessment of the self and which data are collected also has empirical ramifications analysis by Valentine, DuBois, and Cooper (2004) looks spec literature relating self-perceptions to academic outcom findings is that studies that matched the level of self-per ment with particular academic domains (e.g., self-perce ence in mathematics with an evaluation of mathematics sk find larger effect sizes than those that mismatched t assessment and the level of evaluative data. Overall, the (2004) meta-analysis found only very small effects of upon academic achievement, on the order of ,B = .08.

We took some of the lessons of the Valentine et al. (200 analysis to heart in the design of the current study. We u specific self-perceived competence scales for reading and the Renick and Harter (1988) Self-Perception Profile f abled Students (SPPLD), which is an adaptation of Har ception Profile for Children (Harter, 1985) and was dev self-perceived competence in both normal children an LD. The outcome measures were closely matched to th reading and arithmetic subtests of the Wide-Range Ac Third Edition (Jastak & Wilkinson, 1993) . We also loo tionships between self-perception of competence and c ment over time -this should logically be the acid test for (Sattler, 1992; Waters, Bruck, & Seidenberg, 1985) was used to obtain an estimate of IQ. The use of the two-subtest WISC-III short form to provide an IQ estimate for research purposes is well documented (Sattler, 1992) . The Block Design and Vocabulary subtests of the WISC-ILI were administered to all partic ipants. These two subtests were selected because they have excellent reli ability and validity, and correlate highly with the Full Scale score over a wide age range (Sattler, 1992) . For the Vocabulary and Block Design combination, the reliability estimates calculated with the Tellegen and Briggs (1967) procedure are r = 0.91 and r = 0.86 (Sattler, 1992) . The scaled scores were determined for each of the subtests and then added together to determine the total scaled score. The scaled score was converted to the WISC score using a conversion table that estimates the Full Scale IQ based on the sum of the two subtest scaled scores (Sattler, 1992) .

WRAT-3: The Wide Range Achievement Test. WRAT-3: The Wide Range Achievement Test (Jastak & Wilkinson, 1993) is one of the few short, quick measures of achievement in basic academic areas. It has Canadian norms and is very well represented in the research literature.

From the WRAT-3 we chose two subtests, Reading and Math. Although the WRAT-3 yields both raw and standard scores, we chose to use standard scores in our analyses to assess performance and changes in performance relative to the age cohort. We also thought that standard scores were the best choice to match the demands of the SPPLD, which WRAT-3 Mathematics subtest. The mathematics su participant to identify numbers, count, and answer lems of varying levels of complexity. The test-take utes to complete as many items as possible, to a maxim yields both raw and standard scores.

The Self-Perception Profile for Learning Disabled St (Renick & Harter, 1988 ) is a self-report measure fo specific self-perceptions of both children with learnin and normally achieving children in 10 areas: general in reading competence, spelling competence, writing ematics competence, social acceptance, athletic com appearance, behavioural conduct, and global self-wo sists of 46 items with a format designed to reduc socially desirable responses (Renick & Harter, 1988 composed of two contrasting statements (e.g. "Som spell most words BUT other kids find it really words"). The child is asked to decide which statemen or her and then check if that statement is "Really true true for me." Items are scored 1-4, from low self-eva evaluation. The manual for the SPPLD notes that mean range from 2.51 to 3.25. The SPPLD is a close adap Perception Profile for Children (SPPC) (Harter, 19 SPPLD was originally designed for use with studen and Harter (1988) Schneider, 1988; Marsh & Gouvernet, 1989 shares these properties.

The arithmetic subtest of the WRAT-3 was administered in small groups of about 15 participants (i.e., all the consenting children from each class were tested together). The experimenter administered the items while two research assistants circulated to answer possible questions and deal with any problems. In a separate session the same groups performed the SPPLD. The experimenter read each item aloud while the students followed on their own forms and, again, two research assistants circu lated to answer questions and deal with problems. In a break from stan dard procedure, four practice questions (developed by the experi menters) were read to the participants first. This change was intended to train the participants in the format of the SPPLD to ensure compre hension. In a subsequent session, each participant was me perform the Vocabulary and Block Design subtests the reading subtest of the WRAT-3. The research formed this task were trained in the administration o the standardized administration procedures describ manual were used.
At time 2, one year later, the same procedures were WISC-III was not administered a second time.

Zero order correlations of the relevant var The correlation between self-perceived competence at time 1 and at time 2 was 0.597 (p<0.001) for mathematics and 0.587 (p<0.001) for reading. The difference between self-perceived competence scores at time 1 and time 2, and the difference between achievement scores at time scores was assessed by the computation of an error/tolerance ratio (Miller & Kane, 2001 ). The standard error was used as an estimate for the error term (0.827 for the reading change score, 0.837 for the mathematics change scores); the standard deviation was used as an estimate for the tolerance term (10.224 for the reading change score, 10.357 for the math ematics change score). The resulting ratios are 0.827/10.224=0.081 and 0.837/10.357=0.081. Gender differences have been reported in the literature in this area (Harter, 1985) . We used independent samples t-tests to compare the self This content downloaded from 195.176.112.15 on Fri, 06 Aug 2021 00:03:14 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms perceived competence scores at time 1 for males no significant differences in either self-perceiv (t152 = -2.182, n.s.) or self-perceived competenc 1.762, n.s.). The correlation between self-perceived competence at time 1 and achievement at time 2 was 0.527 (p<.001) for reading and 0.442 (p<.001) for mathematics. After partialling out the effects of time 1 achievement, the correlations were 0.306 (p<.01) for reading and 0.251 (p<.001) for mathematics. Self-perceived competence at time 1, however, was not predictive of change in academic performance across time (see Table 3 , for reading, r=0.029, n.s.; for mathematics, r=0.024, n.s.). Neither was change in self-perceived competence related to change in performance between time 1 and time 2 (for reading, r=0.084, n.s.; for mathematics, r=0.142, n.s.).

For the participants in this study, self-perception of com ing and mathematics was a somewhat accurate and m attribute, which was moderately predictive of future counting for roughly 16 per cent to 25 per cent of the v achievement. However, after accounting for the effect o achievement on later achievement, the predictive ability competence becomes more modest, accounting for bet to nine per cent of variance in academic performance More interesting is the finding that self-perceived co did not predict change in achievement between time Although change scores have been viewed with great been shown (Miller & Kane, 2001; Yin & Brennan, 200 scores can be used as reliable and valid indicators of formance over time. The finding of a favourable erro (E/T), which compares the probability of error in t tolerance for error in the score, gives reassurance i change scores in this particular case. If self-perceptio were causal to academic performance, not merely re expect that perception of competence at time 1 would later achievement, but also the change in achievement ov the performance of those participants who rated th competent would be more likely to improve over tim formance of those who rated themselves as less com likely to decline over time. This relationship was not possibility is that change in participants' judgment of th over time would be related to change in performance ov for participants whose self-perceptions of competenc would expect performance to improve over time, and this relationship was not evident. Thus, the data in o support the hypothesis that self-perception of academ particular domains is a causal factor in academic perform Although this study is not the first to investigate the self-perceived competence for various outcomes, it is on look at self-perception in particular academic domains an score to outcomes in those particular domains. This pr number of students using a structural equa these researchers found no causal role for se outcomes. Our study supports and expands upon academic domains.

What are the implications of this study for with other findings, which also dispute perception in academic (and many other) out modulation of self-perception, to affect acad enterprise that should absorb much of any sch time and money. This is not to say that self-p should be ignored. Self-perception may play tional well-being. Heath and Glen (2005) This study should not be interpreted as show ception, in this case self-perceived competence in areas, is unimportant. Rather, this study, among othe interaction of self-perception of academic compet emic performance is not direct or simple (Hoza e Glen, 2005) . Future research should work toward complex aspects of these relationships.

One limitation of this study is the high, stable scores on the self perception measure. The ceiling effect that results from the modal score of 4.0 (the highest possible) damps down variability. It does not elim inate it, however, and 50 per cent of the participants had scores below 4.0. Students who score high on self-perceived competence at time 1 should be among those who improve in performance over time, and vice versa, if self-perceived competence has a causal role. The lack of change in self-perception over time speaks against this causal role because there was significant change in performance. If self-perceived competence were either the cause or the result of changes in performance, it should track change in performance. The lack of change in self-perception despite change in performance strongly implies independence between the two factors.

Another limitation of this study is that measurements were made only one year apart. It is possible, of course, that had the study looked at a longer time span the results might have been different, although no research or theory predicts what time span might be required for a self perception effect to mature. Likewise, a different participant age-group might have shown different results. Perhaps adolescents would be more likely to show the effect of interest. Future research might productively look into other domains, with different instruments having similar domain-specificity, different participant populations and longer dura tions. Family variables may also be important, for instance family background variables (Bachman & O'Malley, 1986) . Clearly, no one
This content downloaded from 195.176.112.15 on Fri, 06 Aug 2021 00:03:14 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms study can address all these variables a necessary.

One of the unique aspects of this study centres on one of the points on which we differ from the recommendations of the Valentine et al. (2004) meta-analysis. This is in the procedure of partialling out variance in time 1 achievement from time 2 achievement scores. Instead, we correlated our self-perception measures directly with the difference in achievement scores between time 1 and time 2. We believe that this test of the hypothesis is more direct than one can infer causality if one can explain change in scores over time, not merely end states. The practice of statistically removing variance attributable to time 1 achievement is not conceptually the same. This process will control for the influence of prior learning on later learning. However, this is a rather artificial conceptlater learning depends completely upon earlier learning having taken place. The use of a change score does not eliminate the influence of prior learning, and does directly represent what must be explained -the changes in achievement which may, or may not, be due to self perception.

Had we used the procedure recommended by Valentine et al. (2004) , we would have reported results much more similar to those arrived at in their review and meta-analysis -partialling out the variance in time 2 achievement due to time 1 achievement yielded a correlation with domain-matched self-perception of roughly r = 0.300. Using this process, we would appear to explain, then, about 9 per cent of the variance in achievement. However, the process we used, correlating change in achievement scores over the year with domain-matched self-perception, yielded correlations of essentially zero. This procedure would indicate that self-perception accounts for no variance in the growth or decline in achievement, an effect size of zero. Thus this study replicates the findings of the Valentine et al. (2004) meta-analysis on one level, but also gives new food for thought in the ongoing debate about self-concept and achievement.

BIBREF42.raw_text: Nancy Heath is an associate professor and Director of the Special Populations program in the Department of Educational and Counselling Psychology at McGill University. Her research is concemed with psychosocial aspects of learning disability, and with self-injurious behaviour. Self-perceptions of competence were general domains, with the modal score at both times being 4 possible.Academic performance was also fairly stable across the period of the study, with the correlations between reading achievement at time 1 and time 2 being 0.755 (p<.001) and between mathematics achievement at time 1 and time 2 being 0.660 (p<.001). Achievement test standard scores were more likely to change between time 1 and time 2 than self perceived competence scores. The median, absolute change in reading achievement was 6 standard score points, in mathematics, 8 standard score points. The mean change in reading achievement between time 1 and time 2 was 2.0 (SD = 10.2), in mathematics achievement, 2.9 (SD = 10.4). Paired-sample t-tests indicated statistically significant differences between time 1 and time 2 reading scores (tl54 = 2.473, p<.05) and math ematics scores (t152 = 3.466, p<.001). Shapiro-Wilk goodness of fit tests indicated that the distributions of the change scores for reading and mathematics did not significantly differ from normality (for reading, W = 0.983, n.s.; for mathematics, W = 0.976, n.s.).
